subsection.title: Introducing comment and feedback systems in user assistance

body.p: help, onlinecomments inHelp authoring tools provide user feedback tools right inside of the topics that you author with the tool. Even a simple link to an email address on each help page so that readers can send email to a centralized mailbox in the department gives your readers a way to give feedback. If you want to structure the feedback, add a web form with specific fields to be filled out before a reader can send it. The help, onlinefeedback toolsfeedback mechanism can send the form via emailusing for customer feedbackemail. Google Forms can populate a Google Spreadsheet with results even as the responses are still coming in. Comments and feedback systems can be incorporated into many online help outputs. Jive Software and JS-Kit are two such offerings. Also, be sure you can track on which pages people are choosing to initiate the comment or response mechanism of your choice.

You may find ways to discover what your readers are doing without requiring their participation to do so, like Will Hill’s “read-wear” phrase and concept discussed in Chapter 6.
